headline: News quiz: Test your knowledge of this week in Berkeley news
subhead: Did you follow the news in Berkeley this week, Oct. 14-19? To take our quiz, choose an answer, and the correct response will appear after you click.

sections.question: Members of which UC Berkeley fraternity recently faced controversy after jokingly posing for a picture with sexual assault protesters?
sections.articleTitle: Members of Phi Gamma Delta fraternity jokingly posed with sexual assault protestors, photo shows
sections.explanation: Campus senior Walker Spence posted a photo that was privately distributed among the Phi Gamma Delta, or Fiji, group chat on Facebook. Spence said in an email that he was spurred to create the post after his housemate, a member of Fiji, sent him the picture.

sections.question: Which Berkeley City Council candidate generated confusion by claiming they are the “1st Asian Candidate” for City Council in 40 years?
sections.explanation: Rosales explained that she was inspired by Ying Lee, the only Asian American to serve on Berkeley City Council in about 40 years. Candidates running in 2018 other than Rosales also identify as Asian American, and Randy Gee and William Shei — who both identified as Asian American — ran for the District 7 seat in the 1990s.

sections.question: A union representing UC librarians has been in contract negotiations with the UC system for how long?
sections.articleTitle: UC librarians begin contract negotiations for higher salaries
sections.explanation: The University Council-American Federation of Teachers, or UC-AFT, has been negotiating with the UC system for higher salaries and sabbatical leave, among other demands. Currently, UC librarians are paid lower salaries than those employed by the California State University system and California community colleges.

sections.question: A UC Berkeley study found that low-income Bay Area residents tend to migrate toward which part of California?
sections.articleTitle: Study finds racial, economic disparities in migration out of Bay Area
sections.explanation: According to the study, low-income Bay Area residents are increasingly limited to the more affordable parts of California for housing. This greatly lowers their access to education options and employment, “marginalizing them economically,” the study said.

sections.question: Which UC Berkeley professor will testify on behalf of Harvard University in a lawsuit over affirmative action?
sections.articleTitle: UC Berkeley professor to serve as key witness for Harvard University in admissions lawsuit
sections.explanation: Harvard University will defend its admissions process using UC Berkeley economics professor David Card’s research, which ultimately found no evidence that Harvard intentionally discriminates against Asian American students. Card is expected to testify against the complainants’ claim that Asian Americans must outperform students from other minority groups to gain admission into Harvard.

sections.question: Berkeley Lab researchers recently discovered that which Egyptian pigment can boost energy efficiency?
sections.articleTitle: Berkeley Lab researchers find ancient pigment can improve energy efficiency
sections.explanation: The ancient pigment can enhance energy efficiency by cooling rooftops and walls and could potentially be applied to the generation of solar energy, according to Berkeley Lab researchers.  The research confirmed that the pigment’s fluorescence, which serves to cool the surface that is absorbing the light, can be 10 times stronger than was previously thought.

sections.question: The City of Berkeley will be providing how many storage lockers for homeless individuals?
sections.articleTitle: City of Berkeley launches program providing storage lockers for homeless individuals
sections.explanation: The program provides lockers with 9 cubic feet of storage space that are accessible on a first-come, first-served basis. Berkeley City Council approved a contract with BOSS on July 24 and agreed to allocate $50,000 to fund the program.

sections.question: How many photograph(s) were stolen from an exhibit at UC Berkeley School of Law’s Human Rights Center?
sections.articleTitle: Photographs of genocide victims stolen from Berkeley Law’s Human Rights Center
sections.explanation: Alexey Berlind, the Human Rights Center’s programs administrator, said that on Monday morning, employees from the Human Rights Center noticed that four of the photographs — two smaller portraits and two larger images from three different walls — were missing.

sections.question: Which UC Berkeley alum will be working with Bancroft Library’s oral history project?
